markdownRemark.html:
Welcome to my (Joshua Tzucker's) collection of personal cheat sheets, technical documentation, and miscellaneous code snippets. Unless indicated otherwise, all content is written and collated by me.

ðŸ’¡ You can use the directory menu (top left button) to easily switch between pages on the site.

ðŸš§ This entire site recently migrated subdomains; apologies for any confusion or outdated links this causes. I will continue redirecting the old subdomain to this one (docs.joshuatz.com) for quite some time.

What Makes Up This Site?

Although I call most of these pages "cheatsheets", they actually come in a wide variety of "flavors". The vast majority of them are indeed cheat sheets / quick reference pages / technical docs, but the full list includes:

  • Cheat Sheets / Technical Documentation

    • These make up the majority of the pages
    • Example: TypeScript Cheat Sheet

  • In depth guides / lessons

    • Example: Intro to JWT

  • Lists and collections

    • Example: "Favorite Programs"

  • Code Snippets / Gists

    • Example: "JavaScript Snippets"

Elevator Pitches - Link

There are so many new things in tech (especially in web dev) to keep track of and learn. I've started a sheet of "elevator pitches" so you don't have to read through 10 paragraphs of marketing fluff just to learn what a new framework does.

Favorite sources - Link

These are some of my favorite places to learn new things, find other cheatsheets, or read about code in general.

Directories

  • Cheatsheets
  • Snippets
  • Settings
  • Snippets
  • Electronics
  • Random
  • Non-Tech

Feedback

At the footer of each page, including this one, is a link to a feedback form. It should auto-populate with the URL from this site. Please let me know if you spot any errors or have any feedback to provide!

Index

Note: Currently, the below list is not automatically generated. However, the directory list that you can access through the menu toggle (top left button) is automatically generated, and should be exhaustive, based on my source filesystem.

  • Favorite Sources
  • Elevator Pitches

  • General

    • General Programming Concepts
    • Dev Job Searching and Interviewing
    • Microsoft Windows

  • APIs

    • Google Maps
    • cloudinary

  • CLI

    • Bash / Shell
    • Windows Cmd / Batch files
    • Init / Scaffolding

  • Databases

    • PostgreSQL
    • MySQL / SQL

  • DevOps

    • General DevOps and Dev Tools
    • Docker
    • Git
    • HTACCESS
  • TypeScript
  • PHP
  • WordPress
  • C++
  • C#
  • .NET
  • Python

  • Javascript

    • Classes
    • DevOps
    • Events
    • Misc (Includes things I often forget)
    • Modules

    • Node and NPM

      • Node: General Notes
      • NPM: General Notes
      • Building an NPM Package
      • Building Cross-Environment NodeJS Packages
      • Express
    • Network requests
    • Newer Stuff
    • Promises and Async/Await
    • Testing
    • Google Apps Scripts (GAS)
    • jsdoc

    • Frameworks

      • Vue

      • React

        • General Notes
        • React Hooks
        • React Performance
      • TypeORM
      • Gatsby JS
      • Svelte
    • Bundlers

  • UI Development & Design

    • CSS and Styling
    • CSS Troubleshooting
    • Web a11y Accessibility
    • HTML Canvas

  • Authentication / Security

    • JWT
    • OAuth
    • MFA
    • Self-Signed SSL Certificates

  • Misc

    • Text and Encodings
    • AutoHotkey
    • Browser Extensions
    • Google Analytics
    • Google Tag Manager
    • Google Sheets
    • Roku
    • TP-Link Kasa / TP-Link Cloud
    • Markdown
    • Social Media
    • Android

    • Beat Saber

  • Snippets

    • bash
    • Windows CMD / Batch
    • JavaScript
    • Online Snippets
    • Regular Expressions

  • Settings

    • VSCode
    • Command Aliases
    • My Favorite Programs

  • Cloud Services

    • Google Cloud Compute (GCP)
    • Microsoft Azure
    • Amazon AWS
    • Zeit

  • Electronics

    • Transistors
    • ESP Modules

  • Non-Tech / Completely Random

    • Cooking / Baking

Build status

Link for more info about how this site works.

Style

I find that writing out a process or tip helps me remember it and cement the details of it in my mind. In addition, if I ever refer back to my notes, it is easier for me to parse my own style of note taking than others'. As such, everything in this repo was written with basically only myself in mind as the expected reader, so take it with a grain of salt.

I also tend to view swapping out more precise and accurate terminology with general descriptors, and even colloquial language or analogies, an acceptable trade-off for increased readability. I think in general, programmers get way too into terminology and end up alienating new coders by using unnecessary extra-precise terms for things that don't actually need them.

TL;DR - I tend to write in a simplified style for myself to read later, that might not always use the right terminology, but tends to get the basic point across. Not for everyone.

Other notes

  • If you see a bunch of stuff added in a single commit, it probably was me moving something from Dropbox or OneNote into this repo. I have collected a decent amount of notes, scratchpads, and cheatsheets over the years and have them in various spots that need to be consolidated into this repo.
markdownRemark.rawMarkdownBody: Welcome to my ([Joshua Tzucker](https://joshuatz.com/?utm_source=cheatsheets)'s) collection of personal cheat sheets, technical documentation, and miscellaneous code snippets. Unless indicated otherwise, all content is written and collated by me. > ðŸ’¡ You can use the directory menu (top left button) to easily switch between pages on the site. > ðŸš§ This entire site recently migrated subdomains; apologies for any confusion or outdated links this causes. I will continue redirecting the old subdomain to this one (`docs.joshuatz.com`) for quite some time. ## What Makes Up This Site? Although I call most of these pages "cheatsheets", they actually come in a wide variety of "flavors". The vast majority of them are indeed cheat sheets / quick reference pages / technical docs, but the full list includes: - Cheat Sheets / Technical Documentation - These make up the majority of the pages - Example: [TypeScript Cheat Sheet](md/cheatsheets/typescript.md) - In depth guides / lessons - Example: [Intro to JWT](md/cheatsheets/security/jwt.md) - Lists and collections - Example: ["Favorite Programs"](md/settings/favorite-programs.md) - Code Snippets / Gists - Example: ["JavaScript Snippets"](md/snippets/js.md) ## Elevator Pitches - [Link](md/elevator-pitches.md) There are so many new things in tech (especially in web dev) to keep track of and learn. I've started a sheet of "elevator pitches" so you don't have to read through 10 paragraphs of marketing fluff just to learn what a new framework does. ## Favorite sources - [Link](md/favorite-sources.md) These are some of my favorite places to learn new things, find other cheatsheets, or read about code in general. ## Directories - [Cheatsheets](md/cheatsheets) - [Snippets](md/snippets) - [Settings](md/settings) - [Snippets](md/snippets) - [Electronics](md/electronics) - [Random](md/random) - [Non-Tech](md/non-tech) ## Feedback At the footer of each page, including this one, is a link to a feedback form.
